channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: German Consumer Confidence Stabilizes Despite Lingering Uncertainty
item.description: German consumers’ willingness to buy is increasing with a key forecast for December showing household sentiment rose for the second time in a row.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: BOJ Rate Hikes Must Proceed With Caution, Board Member Says
item.description: The Bank of Japan should proceed cautiously with interest-rate increases, tightening at a pace that is neither too fast nor too slow, said policy board member Asahi Noguchi.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Bank of Korea Holds Steady as It Flags Higher Growth, Inflation
item.description: South Korea’s central bank maintained its policy rate at 2.50% for the fourth consecutive meeting, staying on the sidelines as it raised its growth and inflation forecasts.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: The job market continues to sputter even as cost and price pressures persist, a Federal Reserve report found, underscoring the competing risks central bank officials will have to weigh next month
item.description: The Federal Reserve’s anecdotal look at the economy shows a sputtering job market and moderate inflation in November.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: The Bank of Mexico lowered its expectation for economic growth this year after a third-quarter contraction that it said showed greater weakness in activity than previously expected
item.description: The central bank said it expects gross domestic product to expand 0.3% this year, less than its previous estimate of 0.6%.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Harrup

item.title: Chicago Business Activity Slumps Unexpectedly
item.description: Business activity in the Chicago area recorded a marked fall in November, driven by declines in orders, production and employment, a monthly survey showed.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Jobless Claims Show Low-Hire, Low-Fire Environment Continues
item.description: The latest batch of weekly jobless-claims data brought more evidence Wednesday that the labor market is stuck in an uncertain neutral: layoffs subdued, but flagging hiring, too.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: New Zealand’s Central Bank Cuts Rates Further to Spark Recovery
item.description: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand lowered interest rates further in an effort to spur recovery in an economy that for now remains moribund, with unemployment at its highest level in nearly a decade.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: Shutdown-delayed data showed American consumers closed out the third quarter on a cautious footing, while a measure of consumer confidence tumbled in November
item.description: American consumers in September reined in spending on tariff-hit categories such as vehicles, electronics and clothing.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: Higher food and energy costs lifted wholesale prices in September, the Labor Department said Tuesday
item.description: Delayed September data will be the most recent official look at inflation available to the central bank at December meeting.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: U.S. Home Prices Slow Further Amid Affordability Concerns
item.description: The S&P Cotality Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, which measures home prices across the country, rose 1.3% in the 12 months through September. This represents the weakest performance since mid-2023.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Parts of Europe at Risk of Downward ‘Spiral’ if Older Voters Stymie Reforms, EBRD Warns
item.description: Economies that escaped from Communism are at risk if older voters and political leaders prevent changes to offset aging populations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Allies of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell have laid the groundwork for him to push a rate cut through a divided committee at December’s meeting even though it could draw multiple dissents
item.description: A divided committee, missing data and a whiff of stagflation present a choice between two paths—each with drawbacks.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly said she supports lowering interest rates at the central bank’s meeting next month
item.description: The views of the San Francisco Fed president are significant because she has rarely deviated publicly from the position of Chair Jerome Powell.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: The Federal Reserve is struggling to persuade some banks to use a lending tool designed to improve the central bank’s control over short-term money markets
item.description: Some banks have been concerned about the appearance of using the standing repo facility, despite the Fed’s assurances.
item.dc:creator: Sam Goldfarb

item.title: U.S. Employment Trends Improved in September Ahead of Shutdown
item.description: The Conference Board’s Employment Trends Index, or ETI, rose in September to 106.84 from an upwardly revised 106.68 in August, which was the lowest since early 2021, according to a delayed release.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: How CEOs got more comfortable with tariffs: We analyzed 5,000 earnings calls to find out
item.description: Trump’s trade war is a pain, but less so than many executives expected.
item.dc:creator: Theo Francis

item.title: Thanksgiving might actually be cheaper this year
item.description: Turkey, stuffing and cranberry prices are all lower, but skip the yams. Sweet potato prices have skyrocketed.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Kuo

item.title: Canadian Retail Trade Remains Soft After Fall in September
item.description: Flat sales seen by Canadian retailers in October point to cracks in the consumers’ resilience as the fallout from the trade war with the U.S. lingers.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Fell in November, Michigan Survey Shows
item.description: The survey’s headline index dropped to 51, hovering near one of the lowest levels in the monthly poll’s history.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Home sales rose to an eight-month high in October, signaling how even a small decline in mortgage rates will attract some buyers back to the market
item.description: Falling mortgage rates spurred more activity in the beleaguered housing market, with sales moving higher for the second consecutive month.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Swiss Watch Exports Continue on Downward Trend in U.S. Tariff Fallout
item.description: Total exports of the timepieces dropped 4.4% in October compared with the same period last year, driven by a U.S. slump.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Figueras

item.title: Trade Deficit Declined in August, Delayed Figures Show
item.description: The U.S. trade deficit shrank in August, the Commerce Department said, giving a delayed look at how tariffs were shaping international trade flows over the summer.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Labor Department Fills in Some Missing Jobless-Claims Data
item.description: A one-off data point has popped into view on the Labor Department’s website: a figure showing that 232,000 Americans filed new unemployment claims in the week through Oct. 18.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Higher Tariffs Take Toll on Global Growth, and Impact Is Set to Linger
item.description: The impact of higher U.S. taxes on imports, while lighter than many feared, will likely persist through next year and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Threats to Eurozone Financial Stability ‘Remain Elevated,’ Says ECB’s De Guindos
item.description: A large-scale trade war has been averted, but uncertainty remains high about government policies that can affect the financial system, the European Central Bank vice president said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: President Trump and his advisers are rushing to try to lower prices for U.S. consumers after voters sent a warning shot to Republicans this month over the high cost of living
item.description: Aside from reducing tariffs, President Trump faces limits in his ability to bring down prices.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Trump moved to lower duties on beef, coffee and dozens of other goods, as he looks for ways to address Americans’ concerns about the cost of living
item.description: The president moved to lower duties on beef, coffee and dozens of other goods, as he looks for ways to address Americans’ concerns about the cost of living.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: The reopened federal government will on Thursday release the first backlogged monthly jobs report, for the month of September
item.description: Widely anticipated labor data starts catch-up on backlogged economic reports after shutdown ended.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Heard on the Street: Borrowing from a builder might get you an eye-catching mortgage rate, but it also means you are more likely to overpay and potentially end up underwater
item.description: Borrowing from a builder might get buyers an eye-catching mortgage rate, but it also means they are more likely to overpay for the property—and potentially end up underwater.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Rise in Key Interest Rate Hit Poorer Households Harder, ECB Economists Say
item.description: Europeans believe that income inequality has increased since the onset of the inflation surge.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Irish Government Might See Boost to Tax Revenues From AI, Weight-Loss Drugs
item.description: Government revenues from taxes on U.S. businesses could rise significantly over coming years, despite higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Big employers are taking a more cautious approach to holiday hiring this year
item.description: Large companies say they are likely to add far fewer seasonal workers than in other recent years.
item.dc:creator: Jared Mitovich

item.title: Europe’s Economic Recovery Hopes Hang on Scarred Consumers
item.description: While the economy appears to have survived a jump in U.S. tariffs, households will have to put half a decade of trauma behind them if the region is to significantly recover.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: New homes are sitting unsold, despite the discounted mortgages that builders are offering
item.description: New homes are sitting unsold, despite builders using sweeteners to shift inventory.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: More home-purchase agreements are being scrapped around the country, reflecting a growing standoff between buyers and sellers in a largely stalled housing market
item.description: Buyers worried about job prospects are getting cold feet, or realizing that costs will be higher than expected.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher
